name: Granite
description: Granite is a coarse-grained igneous rock composed mainly of quartz, feldspar, and mica. It is typically light-colored, ranging from white to gray or pink, with specks of darker minerals scattered throughout. Granite is known for its durability and strength, making it a popular choice for construction and architectural purposes. It is commonly used as a building material for countertops, flooring, and monuments. With its attractive appearance and ability to withstand weathering and erosion, granite is also frequently used in decorative applications.

name: Basalt
description: Basalt is a fine-grained igneous rock that is commonly dark in color, ranging from black to gray. It is formed from the rapid cooling of lava on the Earth's surface. Basalt is known for its dense and durable nature, making it a common material for construction and paving. It often exhibits a columnar structure due to the contraction and cracking of the rock as it cools. Basalt can be found in volcanic regions around the world and is used in various applications such as road construction, building foundations, and as an aggregate in concrete.

name: Limestone
description: Limestone is a sedimentary rock primarily composed of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) in the form of mineral calcite. It forms from the accumulation of shells, coral, algae, and other organic materials over millions of years. Limestone often has a light color, ranging from white to gray, but can also exhibit various shades of yellow, brown, and even blue. It has a relatively soft texture and can be easily scratched with a fingernail. Limestone is commonly used as a building material and for various applications such as cement production, road construction, and as a component in the manufacturing of glass and ceramics. It also serves as an important geological resource and contains valuable fossils and geological information about Earth's history

name: Sandstone
description: Sandstone is a sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-sized mineral particles or rock fragments. It is formed through the consolidation and cementation of sand grains over time. Sandstone typically has a granular texture and can vary in color, ranging from light beige or yellow to red, brown, or even gray. It is known for its high porosity and permeability, allowing it to hold and transmit water. Sandstone is commonly used as a building material, especially in construction projects that require durable and weather-resistant materials. It is also used for decorative purposes, such as in landscaping and architecture. Sandstone can preserve fossils and provide important geological information about past environments and climates.

name: Slate
description: Slate is a fine-grained metamorphic rock that is characterized by its smooth and flat surfaces. It is formed from the compression and metamorphism of shale or clay-rich sedimentary rocks. Slate typically exhibits a distinctive layered structure, known as foliation, which gives it its characteristic appearance. It is often found in shades of gray, but can also occur in other colors such as green, red, or purple. Slate is valued for its durability, low porosity, and resistance to weathering, making it a popular choice for roofing, flooring, and decorative purposes. It is easily split into thin sheets, making it suitable for various construction and design applications. Additionally, slate has been used for centuries as a writing surface, particularly in the form of slate tiles or slate boards.

name: Diorite
description: Diorite is a coarse-grained igneous rock that is composed primarily of plagioclase feldspar, biotite, and hornblende minerals. It typically exhibits a speckled appearance due to the contrasting colors of its mineral constituents. Diorite is intermediate in composition between granite and gabbro, with a moderate silica content. It is commonly gray in color, but can also range from light to dark gray, greenish-gray, or black. Diorite is known for its durability and strength, making it suitable for various construction purposes such as building facades, countertops, and decorative stones. It often occurs in intrusive igneous formations, including as part of mountain ranges and batholiths.

name: Gabbro
description: Gabbro is a coarse-grained, dark-colored igneous rock that is composed mainly of plagioclase feldspar, pyroxene, and sometimes olivine. It is similar in composition to basalt but has larger mineral grains due to its slow cooling and crystallization deep within the Earth's crust. Gabbro typically appears as a dark gray to black rock with a uniform texture. It is known for its durability and strength, making it suitable for a wide range of construction applications, including as dimension stone, crushed stone for road construction, and as an aggregate in concrete. Gabbro is commonly found in large intrusive bodies known as plutons and is a significant component of the oceanic crust.

name: Obsidian
description: Obsidian is a natural volcanic glass that forms when molten lava cools rapidly with minimal crystal growth. It is usually black or dark brown in color, although it can also be green, red, or other colors depending on impurities. Obsidian has a smooth, glassy texture and is known for its sharp edges and conchoidal fracture, making it useful in ancient times for tools, weapons, and decorative objects. It is formed in areas of volcanic activity and is often associated with volcanic domes, lava flows, and pyroclastic deposits. Due to its unique appearance and sharpness, obsidian is still used today in jewelry-making, sculpture, and as a material for surgical scalpels.

name: Pumice
description: Pumice is a light and porous volcanic rock that forms when lava with high gas content rapidly cools and solidifies. It is typically light gray or white in color and has a frothy appearance due to the presence of countless gas bubbles trapped in the rock. Pumice is extremely lightweight and can even float on water. It has a rough texture and is often used as an abrasive material for exfoliating skin, cleaning surfaces, and polishing. Pumice is also utilized in horticulture as a soil amendment to improve drainage and aeration. Additionally, it is sometimes incorporated into lightweight concrete and as a component in certain building materials.

name: Rhyolite
description: Rhyolite is a fine-grained volcanic rock that is light in color, typically ranging from light gray to pink or tan. It forms from the rapid cooling and solidification of magma or lava rich in silica content. Rhyolite is composed mainly of quartz, feldspar, and small amounts of other minerals. It has a smooth texture and may contain visible crystals or a glassy appearance. Rhyolite can be found in various volcanic regions around the world and is often associated with explosive volcanic eruptions. It is commonly used as a decorative stone in landscaping and construction due to its attractive colors and durability.

name: Andesite
description: Andesite is a volcanic rock that is intermediate in composition between basalt and rhyolite. It typically has a gray to dark gray color and a fine-grained texture. Andesite forms from the cooling and solidification of magma or lava that is rich in silica and contains minerals such as plagioclase feldspar, amphibole, and pyroxene. It is commonly found in volcanic areas associated with subduction zones, where tectonic plates collide. Andesite has good strength and durability, making it suitable for a variety of construction purposes, including building stones and road aggregates. It is also used in the production of concrete and as a decorative stone.

name: Pegmatite
description: Pegmatite is an igneous rock that is characterized by its exceptionally large crystals. It forms in the final stages of magma cooling and is often found in association with granite. Pegmatite crystals can reach impressive sizes, ranging from centimeters to several meters in length. The crystals within pegmatite are typically composed of minerals such as quartz, feldspar, and mica, but can also include rare and valuable minerals like beryl, tourmaline, and spodumene. Due to the presence of these unique minerals, pegmatite deposits are often mined for gemstones and valuable ores. Pegmatite is also used as a source of industrial minerals and is sometimes quarried for its aesthetic value as a decorative stone.

name: Peridotite
description: Peridotite is a coarse-grained, ultramafic igneous rock composed primarily of the mineral olivine. It is one of the main rock types in the Earth's upper mantle and is associated with the formation of oceanic crust. Peridotite has a dark green to grayish color and a dense, heavy texture. It is rich in iron and magnesium, giving it a high density. Due to its high melting point and low silica content, peridotite is not commonly found at the Earth's surface but can be exposed through tectonic forces or volcanic activity. It is used in various applications, including as a source of gem-quality peridot and as a refractory material in high-temperature industrial processes.

name: Scoria
description: Scoria is a dark-colored, extrusive volcanic rock with a vesicular texture. It is formed when molten lava is rapidly cooled and solidified, trapping gas bubbles within the rock. The trapped gas bubbles create a porous and lightweight structure. Scoria is typically black or dark brown in color and has a rough, vesicular surface. It is commonly found in volcanic areas and is often used as a decorative landscaping material due to its unique texture and color. It is also used in construction, road building, and as a lightweight aggregate in concrete.

name: Tuff
description: Tuff is a type of rock formed from the consolidation of volcanic ash and other volcanic materials. It is created when volcanic eruptions eject ash and pyroclastic debris into the air, which then settles and accumulates on the ground. Over time, the loose volcanic fragments become compacted and cemented together, forming a solid rock. Tuff typically has a porous and lightweight structure due to the presence of air-filled voids. It can vary in color, ranging from light to dark, depending on the composition of the volcanic materials. Tuff is commonly used as a building material, especially in areas with volcanic activity, and it is also valued for its aesthetic appeal in landscaping and architecture.

name: Shale
description: Shale is a fine-grained sedimentary rock composed mainly of clay minerals. It forms from the compaction and cementation of silt and clay particles over long periods of time. Shale has a layered or laminated structure and is characterized by its ability to split into thin sheets. It typically has a smooth texture and can range in color from gray and black to brown and red, depending on the presence of organic matter and mineral content. Shale is an important rock in the petroleum industry as it serves as a source rock for the production of oil and natural gas. It is also used in construction, as a raw material for making bricks, and in the production of ceramics.

name: Conglomerate
description: Conglomerate is a coarse-grained sedimentary rock that is composed of rounded or angular fragments of various rock types and mineral grains held together by a matrix of finer-grained sediment or mineral cement. It forms through the process of sediment deposition and compaction, typically in high-energy environments such as riverbeds, alluvial fans, or near shorelines. Conglomerate can vary in color, texture, and composition depending on the types of rocks and minerals present in the sediment source. It is often characterized by its distinct pebble-sized or larger clasts, which give it a rough and bumpy appearance. Conglomerate is commonly used in construction and as decorative stone due to its durability and attractive appearance.

name: Breccia
description: Breccia is a type of coarse-grained sedimentary rock that is composed of angular fragments of various rock types and mineral grains. It forms through the process of sediment deposition and lithification, typically in environments where there has been significant rock fragmentation, such as fault zones or areas of intense tectonic activity. The angular fragments in breccia can range in size from pebbles to larger boulders and are cemented together by a matrix of finer-grained sediment or mineral cement. Breccia can exhibit a variety of colors and textures depending on the types of rocks and minerals present in the fragments. It is commonly used in construction and as decorative stone due to its unique appearance and strength.

name: Chalk
description: Chalk is a soft, fine-grained, porous sedimentary rock composed primarily of the remains of tiny marine organisms called coccolithophores. It is usually white in color and has a powdery texture. Chalk forms in shallow marine environments where the accumulation of coccoliths, the microscopic skeletal structures of the organisms, creates layers of sediment over time. It is commonly associated with cliffs and coastal areas. Chalk has been widely used throughout history as a writing surface, particularly in the form of chalkboards and chalk sticks. It also has various industrial applications, such as in the production of cement and as a filler material in products like paints and plastics.

name: Coal
description: Coal is a sedimentary rock that forms from the accumulation of organic matter, mainly plant material, in swampy environments over millions of years. It is primarily composed of carbon, along with various other elements and minerals. Coal is a combustible rock, meaning it can be burned as a fuel to release heat energy. It is typically black or dark brown in color and has a relatively high carbon content. Coal has been a significant source of energy for centuries and is used extensively for electricity generation, industrial processes, and heating. It is also a major source of carbon dioxide emissions and a subject of environmental concern due to its impact on climate change.

name: Dolomite
description: Dolomite is a sedimentary rock that belongs to the carbonate group of minerals. It is primarily composed of calcium magnesium carbonate, with the chemical formula CaMg(CO3)2. Dolomite typically forms as a result of the alteration of limestone or lime-rich sedimentary rocks through a process known as dolomitization. It is known for its distinctive white, gray, or pinkish color and often exhibits a fine-grained texture. Dolomite is used in a variety of applications, including as a construction and decorative stone, in the production of cement and asphalt, as a soil conditioner in agriculture, and as a source of magnesium in industrial processes.

name: Flint
description: Flint is a hard, sedimentary form of cryptocrystalline quartz. It typically occurs as nodules or layers in sedimentary rocks such as limestone. Flint is known for its characteristic dark gray to black color and conchoidal fracture, which produces sharp edges when fractured. It has been used by humans for thousands of years to create tools and weapons due to its ability to hold a sharp edge. Flint is also valued for its fire-starting properties, as it can produce sparks when struck against a hard surface. In addition to its historical significance, flint is still used today in various applications such as making flintlock firearms, crafting jewelry, and as an abrasive material.

name: Gypsum
description: Gypsum is a soft sulfate mineral that is composed of calcium sulfate dihydrate. It typically forms as an evaporite mineral, meaning it is deposited from water solutions that have become concentrated through the evaporation of water. Gypsum has a white to gray color and a silky or glassy appearance. It is known for its characteristic property of easily being scratched by a fingernail. Gypsum is widely used in various industries, including construction, as it is a major component in the production of plaster, drywall, and cement. It is also used in agriculture as a soil conditioner and in the manufacturing of fertilizers. Additionally, gypsum has some uses in the field of art and decoration, where it is employed in sculptures, molds, and ornamental designs.

name: Lignite
description: Lignite is a type of coal that is considered to be the lowest rank of coal due to its relatively low carbon content and energy value. It is a brownish-black sedimentary rock that is formed from the compressed and partially decayed remains of plants in swampy environments. Lignite has a relatively high moisture content and a soft texture, making it less dense and more crumbly compared to other types of coal. It is commonly used as a fuel for power generation and in industrial processes, particularly in areas where it is abundant. However, due to its lower energy content and higher moisture content, lignite is less efficient and emits more carbon dioxide when burned compared to higher-grade coals.

name: Chert
description: Chert is a hard, dense, and fine-grained sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline quartz. It often displays a conchoidal fracture, meaning it breaks with smooth, curved surfaces similar to the shape of a clamshell. Chert can come in various colors, including white, gray, brown, black, or red, and it is commonly found as nodules or layers within other rocks. It forms through the deposition of silica-rich materials, such as the remains of marine organisms or the precipitation of silica from groundwater. Chert has been used by humans throughout history for making tools, weapons, and decorative objects due to its hardness and ability to hold a sharp edge. It is also a common component of sedimentary rocks and can serve as a reservoir for groundwater.

name: Oolite
description: Oolite is a sedimentary rock composed of small spherical grains called ooids. These ooids typically consist of concentric layers of calcium carbonate or other minerals. The formation of ooids occurs in shallow marine environments where loose sediment is continuously rolled and coated by precipitation of mineral-rich water. Oolite can vary in color and composition, with common types including limestone oolite and ironstone oolite. It often exhibits a unique texture resembling a collection of fish eggs or small spheres, giving it a distinct appearance. Oolite rocks are commonly used in construction and as decorative stones due to their appealing texture and durability. Additionally, they can provide valuable clues about ancient environments and geological processes.

name: Travertine
description: Travertine is a type of sedimentary rock that forms from the precipitation of minerals in groundwater, usually in and around limestone caves or hot springs. It is primarily composed of calcium carbonate, typically derived from the dissolution of limestone. Travertine has a distinct porous and layered structure, with visible holes and voids often filled with additional minerals or sediment. Its colors range from white and cream to tan, brown, and even red, depending on the impurities present during its formation. Travertine is commonly used as a building material for its aesthetic appeal, durability, and versatility. It is utilized in various applications, including flooring, countertops, wall cladding, and decorative elements.

name: Siltstone
description: Siltstone is a fine-grained sedimentary rock composed primarily of silt-sized particles. It forms through the accumulation and compaction of fine-grained sediment, typically deposited in environments such as river floodplains, lakes, and deltas. Siltstone has a smooth texture and a compacted appearance, often exhibiting layers or bedding planes. It usually appears in shades of gray, brown, or red, depending on the mineral content. Due to its fine-grained nature, siltstone exhibits low permeability and is often characterized by its ability to retain water. It is commonly used as a construction material, in landscaping, and for decorative purposes.

name: Peat
description: Peat is a type of organic sedimentary material composed of partially decayed plant matter. It forms in wetland environments with high levels of moisture and low oxygen, where the decomposition of organic material is slow. Peat is typically found in marshes, bogs, and swamps. It has a dark brown to black color and a fibrous texture. Due to its high carbon content, peat is often used as a fuel source, particularly in regions where it is abundant. It is also used in horticulture for soil conditioning and as a component in potting mixes. Peat plays an important role in carbon sequestration and the preservation of plant fossils.

name: Loess
description: Loess rock is a type of sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of silt-sized particles deposited by the wind. It is characterized by its fine-grained texture, typically consisting of loosely packed, unconsolidated particles. Loess rock is typically light yellow or buff in color and lacks significant cementation or consolidation. It is commonly found in extensive deposits, often forming thick layers or blankets. Due to its porous nature, loess rock has good water retention properties and is known for its fertility, making it suitable for agricultural purposes. The deposition of loess rock is often associated with glacial and desert environments where wind action is prevalent.

name: Mudstone
description: Mudstone is a type of sedimentary rock that consists of fine-grained particles, predominantly clay and silt, compacted together. It has a smooth texture and is often characterized by its ability to split into thin layers. Mudstone forms in low-energy depositional environments such as lakes, river floodplains, and deep ocean basins. It commonly exhibits a gray or brown color, although it can also appear in various shades of red and green. Mudstone is important in geology as it preserves valuable information about past environments and is often used as a source rock for oil and gas reservoirs.

name: Oil Shale
description: Oil shale rock is a sedimentary rock that contains organic matter known as kerogen, which can be converted into oil through a heating process called pyrolysis. It is characterized by its dark color and fine-grained texture. Oil shale rock is rich in hydrocarbon potential, making it a valuable source of unconventional oil and gas. However, extracting oil from oil shale is a complex and energy-intensive process. Oil shale deposits are found in various regions globally and have significant implications for energy production and resource exploration.

name: Arkose
description: Arkose is a type of sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of sand-sized grains of quartz and feldspar, along with smaller amounts of other minerals. It typically has a coarse-grained texture and often exhibits a reddish or brownish color due to the presence of iron oxide minerals. Arkose forms in environments where there is a high supply of sediment, such as river channels or alluvial plains. It is commonly associated with the erosion of granitic or metamorphic rocks, with the weathering and transport of these materials leading to the deposition and eventual consolidation of the arkose sediment. Arkose is used in various applications, including as a building stone, aggregate in construction, and as a reservoir rock for groundwater.

name: Greywacke
description: Greywacke is a type of sedimentary rock that is characterized by its gray color and rugged appearance. It is composed of a mixture of fine-grained clay and sand-sized particles, along with varying amounts of other minerals such as quartz, feldspar, and mica. Greywacke often exhibits a compacted and hardened texture, and it is commonly found in regions where there has been intense tectonic activity and the accumulation of sedimentary materials. It is known for its durability and strength, making it suitable for various construction purposes, including as a building stone and as an aggregate in road construction. Greywacke can be found in mountainous regions, river valleys, and ancient marine environments.

name: Phosphorite
description: Phosphorite is a sedimentary rock that is rich in phosphate minerals. It forms through the accumulation of organic remains and the precipitation of phosphate minerals in marine environments. Phosphorite is typically found in nodular or bedded forms and can have various colors including white, yellow, and brown. It is valued for its high phosphorus content, which makes it an important source of phosphorus for fertilizers and other industrial applications. Phosphorite deposits are often associated with ancient marine basins and areas with abundant marine life.

name: Marble
description: Marble is a metamorphic rock that forms from the recrystallization of limestone or dolomite under high pressure and temperature conditions. It is known for its stunning beauty and elegant appearance, characterized by its smooth texture and wide range of colors and patterns. Marble is composed primarily of calcite or dolomite crystals, which give it a distinct veined or mottled appearance. It is a popular choice for sculptures, architectural elements, and decorative purposes due to its aesthetic appeal and durability. Marble has been used throughout history in various famous structures, art pieces, and monuments, showcasing its timeless elegance and cultural significance.

name: Quartzite
description: Quartzite is a metamorphic rock formed from the recrystallization of quartz-rich sandstone under intense heat and pressure. It is known for its remarkable hardness and durability, making it a popular choice for a wide range of applications. Quartzite typically exhibits a granular texture and comes in various colors, including white, gray, and shades of pink. Its resistance to heat, abrasion, and chemical weathering, coupled with its natural beauty, make quartzite a sought-after material for countertops, flooring, wall cladding, and decorative purposes. Whether used in interior or exterior design, quartzite adds elegance and strength to any space.

name: Schist
description: Schist is a metamorphic rock characterized by its foliated texture, consisting of aligned mineral grains. It forms from the transformation of pre-existing rocks under high heat and pressure. Schist commonly contains minerals such as mica, chlorite, garnet, and graphite, giving it a distinct appearance and often exhibiting a shimmering or layered appearance. The texture and composition of schist can vary, resulting in different types such as mica schist, garnet schist, and graphite schist. Schist is valued for its decorative qualities and is commonly used as a building material, for landscaping, and as a component in sculptures and ornamental objects.

name: Gneiss
description: Gneiss is a metamorphic rock characterized by its banded or foliated appearance, resulting from the recrystallization of pre-existing rocks under high temperature and pressure. It typically exhibits alternating layers or bands of different minerals, giving it a distinct texture. Gneiss is composed of minerals such as quartz, feldspar, mica, and amphibole, and its color and composition can vary widely. It is known for its durability, strength, and aesthetic appeal, making it a popular choice for various applications, including building materials, countertops, and decorative stone. Gneiss is also used in the construction of monuments and sculptures due to its pleasing appearance and ability to take a high polish.

name: Amphibolite
description: Amphibolite is a metamorphic rock that primarily consists of amphibole minerals, such as hornblende. It typically forms through the metamorphism of basaltic or gabbroic rocks, where the original minerals recrystallize and align to create a foliated texture. Amphibolite is known for its dark color, often appearing greenish or black, and its characteristic sheen. It is a durable and hard rock with excellent strength and resistance to weathering. Amphibolite is commonly used as a decorative stone in construction and landscaping projects due to its attractive appearance and ability to take a polish. It also has industrial applications, such as in the production of crushed stone and aggregates for road construction and railway ballast.

name: Phyllite
description: A type of foliated metamorphic rock created from slate that is further metamorphosed so that very fine grained white mica achieves a preferred orientation.

name: Migmatite
description: A rock at the frontier between igneous and metamorphic rocks. They can also be known as diatexite.
wikiExtract: Migmatite is a composite rock found in medium and high-grade metamorphic environments, commonly within Precambrian cratonic blocks. It consists of two or more constituents often layered repetitively: one layer is an older metamorphic rock that was reconstituted subsequently by partial melting ("neosome"), while the alternate layer has a pegmatitic, aplitic, granitic or generally plutonic appearance ("paleosome"). Commonly, migmatites occur below deformed metamorphic rocks that represent the base of eroded mountain chains.Migmatites form under extreme temperature and pressure conditions during prograde metamorphism, when partial melting occurs in metamorphic paleosome. Components exsolved by partial melting are called neosome (meaning ‘new body’), which may or may not be heterogeneous at the microscopic to macroscopic scale. Migmatites often appear as tightly, incoherently folded veins (ptygmatic folds).
wikiDescription: Mixture of metamorphic rock and igneous rock

name: Eclogite
description: A high-pressure, high-temperature metamorphic rock that forms from basaltic and gabbroic precursors.
wikiExtract: Eclogite ( ) is a metamorphic rock containing garnet (almandine-pyrope) hosted in a matrix of sodium-rich pyroxene (omphacite). Accessory minerals include kyanite, rutile, quartz, lawsonite, coesite, amphibole, phengite, paragonite, zoisite, dolomite, corundum and, rarely, diamond. The chemistry of primary and accessory minerals is used to classify three types of eclogite (A, B, and C). The broad range of eclogitic compositions has led a longstanding debate on the origin of eclogite xenoliths as subducted, altered oceanic crust.
wikiDescription: A dense metamorphic rock formed under high pressure

name: Soapstone
description: A type of metamorphic rock that is largely composed of the mineral talc, and is thus rich in magnesium.
wikiExtract: Soapstone (also known as steatite or soaprock) is a talc-schist, which is a type of metamorphic rock.  It is composed largely of the magnesium rich mineral talc.  It is produced by dynamothermal metamorphism and metasomatism, which occur in the zones where tectonic plates are subducted, changing rocks by heat and pressure, with influx of fluids, but without melting. It has been a medium for carving for thousands of years.
wikiDescription: Talc-bearing metamorphic rock

name: Blueschist
description: A metavolcanic rock that forms by the metamorphism of basalt and rocks with similar composition at high pressures and low temperatures.
wikiExtract:
Blueschist ( ), also called glaucophane schist, is a metavolcanic rock that forms by the metamorphism of basalt and rocks with similar composition at high pressures and low temperatures (200–500 °C (392–932 °F)), approximately corresponding to a depth of 15–30 km (9.3–18.6 mi). The blue color of the rock comes from the presence of the predominant minerals glaucophane and lawsonite.
Blueschists are schists typically found within orogenic belts as terranes of lithology in faulted contact with greenschist or rarely eclogite facies rocks.
wikiDescription: Type of metavolcanic rock

name: Greenstone
description: An altered basalt or chert. It is often used by gold miners for it often contains gold.
wikiExtract: Greenstone may refer to:
wikiDescription: Topics referred to by the same term

name: Serpentinite
description: A rock composed of one or more serpentine group minerals. Minerals in this group are formed by serpentinization, a hydration and metamorphic transformation of ultramafic rock from the Earth's mantle.
wikiExtract: Serpentinite is a rock composed predominantly of one or more serpentine group minerals, the name originating from the similarity of the texture of the rock to that of the skin of a snake. Serpentinite has been called serpentine or serpentine rock, particularly in older geological texts and in wider cultural settings.
wikiDescription: Rock formed by hydration and metamorphic transformation of olivine

name: Hornfels
description: A fine-grained metamorphic rock formed by the action of heat on clay rocks, known as contact metamorphism.
wikiExtract: Hornfels is the group name for a set of contact metamorphic rocks that have been baked and hardened by the heat of intrusive igneous masses and have been rendered massive, hard, splintery, and in some cases exceedingly tough and durable. These properties are due to fine grained non-aligned crystals with platy or prismatic habits, characteristic of metamorphism at high temperature but without accompanying deformation.  The term is derived from the German word Hornfels, meaning "hornstone", because of its exceptional toughness and texture both reminiscent of animal horns. These rocks were referred to by miners in northern England as whetstones.Most hornfels are fine-grained, and while the original rocks (such as sandstone, shale, slate and limestone) may have been more or less fissile owing to the presence of bedding or cleavage planes, this structure is effaced or rendered inoperative in the hornfels. Though many hornfels show vestiges of the original bedding, they break across this as readily as along it; in fact, they tend to separate into cubical fragments rather than into thin plates.

name: Myrmekite
description: A texture found in granitic rocks, consisting of irregular rims of quartz surrounding and replacing feldspar.
wikiExtract: Myrmekite is a vermicular, or wormy, intergrowth of quartz in plagioclase. The intergrowths are microscopic in scale, typically with maximum dimensions less than 1 millimeter. The plagioclase is sodium-rich, usually albite or oligoclase.  These quartz-plagioclase intergrowths are associated with and commonly in contact with potassium feldspar. Myrmekite is formed under metasomatic conditions, usually in conjunction with tectonic deformations.
wikiDescription: Tiny intergrowths of quartz and feldspar in rocks

name: Glaucophane-Schist
description: A type of blueschist composed predominantly of the blue amphibole glaucophane and the mica mineral muscovite.

name: Pseudotachylite
description: A dark, glassy vein filling or fault rock, created by frictional melting and/or decomposition of rocks.
wikiExtract: Pseudotachylyte (sometimes written as pseudotachylite) is an extremely fine-grained to glassy, dark, cohesive rock occurring as veins that form through frictional melting and subsequent quenching during earthquakes, large-scale landslides, and impacts events. Chemical composition of pseudotachylyte generally reflects the local bulk chemistry, though may skew to slightly more mafic compositions due to the preferential incorporation of hydrous and ferro-magnesian minerals (mica and amphibole, respectively) into the melt phase.Pseudotachylyte was first documented by Shand in the Vredefort Impact Structure and was named due to its close resemblance to tachylyte, a basaltic glass. Though pseudotachylyte is reported to have a glassy appearance, they are extremely susceptible to alteration and are thus rarely found to be entirely composed of glass. Typically, they are completely devitrified into a very fine-grained material with quench textures such as chilled margins, radial and concentric clusters of microcrystalites (spherulites) or as radial overgrowths of microcrystalites on clasts, as well as skeletal and spinifex microcrystalites.
wikiDescription: Glassy, or very fine-grained, rock type

name: Granulite
description: A metamorphic rock that experienced high-temperature and moderate-pressure metamorphism.
wikiExtract:
Granulites are a class of high-grade metamorphic rocks of the granulite facies that have experienced high-temperature and moderate-pressure metamorphism. They are medium to coarse–grained and mainly composed of feldspars sometimes associated with quartz and anhydrous ferromagnesian minerals, with granoblastic texture and gneissose to massive structure. They are of particular interest to geologists because many granulites represent samples of the deep continental crust. Some granulites experienced decompression from deep in the Earth to shallower crustal levels at high temperature; others cooled while remaining at depth in the Earth.
The minerals present in a granulite will vary depending on the parent rock of the granulite and the temperature and pressure conditions experienced during metamorphism.
wikiDescription: Class of high-grade medium to coarse grained metamorphic rocks

name: Skarn
description: A metamorphic rock that has been chemically and mineralogically altered by metasomatism.
wikiExtract: Skarns or tactites are hard, coarse-grained metamorphic rocks that form by a process called metasomatism. Skarns tend to be rich in calcium-magnesium-iron-manganese-aluminium silicate minerals, which are also referred to as calc-silicate minerals. These minerals form as a result of alteration which occurs when hydrothermal fluids interact with a protolith of either igneous or sedimentary origin. In many cases, skarns are associated with the intrusion of a granitic pluton found in and around faults or shear zones that commonly intrude into a carbonate layer composed of either dolomite or limestone. Skarns can form by regional, or contact metamorphism and therefore form in relatively high temperature environments.
wikiDescription: Hard, coarse-grained, hydrothermally altered metamorphic rocks

name: Dunite
description: Dunite typically undergoes retrograde metamorphism in near-surface environments and is altered to serpentinite and soapstone.
wikiExtract: Dunite (/ˈduːnaɪt, ˈdʌnaɪt/), also known as olivinite (not to be confused with the mineral olivenite), is an intrusive igneous rock of ultramafic composition and with phaneritic (coarse-grained) texture. The mineral assemblage is greater than 90% olivine, with minor amounts of other minerals such as pyroxene, chromite, magnetite, and pyrope. Dunite is the olivine-rich endmember of the peridotite group of mantle-derived rocks.
wikiDescription: Hard, coarse-grained, hydrothermally altered metamorphic rocks

name: Aplite
description: Aplite is an intrusive igneous rock in which the mineral composition is the same as granite, but in which the grains are much finer, under 1 mm across. Quartz and feldspar are the dominant minerals.
wikiDescription: Aplite is and composed mainly of quartz and alkali-feldspar with very small amounts of muscovite and biotite. Aplite is mostly fine grain, white to light gray in color.

name: Granite
description: A very hard, granular, crystalline, igneous rock consisting mainly of quartz, mica, and feldspar and often used as a building stone.
wikiExtract:
Granite () is a coarse-grained (phaneritic) intrusive igneous rock composed mostly of quartz, alkali feldspar, and plagioclase. It forms from magma with a high content of silica and alkali metal oxides that slowly cools and solidifies underground. It is common in the continental crust of Earth, where it is found in igneous intrusions. These range in size from dikes only a few centimeters across to batholiths exposed over hundreds of square kilometers.
Granite is typical of a larger family of granitic rocks, or granitoids, that are composed mostly of coarse-grained quartz and feldspars in varying proportions.
wikiDescription: Common type of intrusive, felsic, igneous rock with granular structure

name: Basalt
description: A dark, fine-grained volcanic rock that sometimes displays a columnar structure, typically composed largely of plagioclase with pyroxene and olivine.
wikiExtract: Basalt (UK: ; US: ) is an aphanitic (fine-grained) extrusive igneous rock formed from the rapid cooling of low-viscosity lava rich in magnesium and iron (mafic lava) exposed at or very near the surface of a rocky planet or moon. More than 90% of all volcanic rock on Earth is basalt. Rapid-cooling, fine-grained basalt is chemically equivalent to slow-cooling, coarse-grained gabbro. The eruption of basalt lava is observed by geologists at about 20 volcanoes per year. Basalt is also an important rock type on other planetary bodies in the Solar System.
wikiDescription: Magnesium- and iron-rich extrusive igneous rock

name: Limestone
description: A sedimentary rock composed primarily of calcite or dolomite. The rock includes also traces of fossils of calcite-secreting organisms.
wikiExtract: Limestone (calcium carbonate CaCO3) is a type of carbonate sedimentary rock which is the main source of the material lime. It is composed mostly of the minerals calcite and aragonite, which are different crystal forms of CaCO3. Limestone forms when these minerals precipitate out of water containing dissolved calcium. This can take place through both biological and nonbiological processes, though biological processes, such as the accumulation of corals and shells in the sea, have likely been more important for the last 540 million years. Limestone often contains fossils which provide scientists with information on ancient environments and on the evolution of life.About 20% to 25% of sedimentary rock is carbonate rock, and most of this is limestone.
wikiDescription: Sedimentary rocks made of calcium carbonate

name: Sandstone
description: A type of rock made from sediment — a sedimentary rock. The sediment particles are clasts, or pieces, of minerals and fragments of rock, thus sandstone is a clastic sedimentary rock.
wikiExtract:
Sandstone is a clastic sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-sized (0.0625 to 2 mm) silicate grains. Sandstones comprise about 20–25% of all sedimentary rocks.Most sandstone is composed of quartz or feldspar (both silicates) because they are the most resistant minerals to weathering processes at the Earth's surface. Like uncemented sand, sandstone may be any color due to impurities within the minerals, but the most common colors are tan, brown, yellow, red, grey, pink, white, and black. Since sandstone beds often form highly visible cliffs and other topographic features, certain colors of sandstone have been strongly identified with certain regions.
Rock formations that are primarily composed of sandstone usually allow the percolation of water and other fluids and are porous enough to store large quantities, making them valuable aquifers and petroleum reservoirs.Quartz-bearing sandstone can be changed into quartzite through metamorphism, usually related to tectonic compression within orogenic belts.
wikiDescription: Type of sedimentary rock

name: Slate
description: A fine-grained, foliated, homogeneous metamorphic rock derived from an original shale-type sedimentary rock composed of clay or volcanic ash through low-grade regional metamorphism.
wikiExtract: Slate is a fine-grained, foliated, homogeneous, metamorphic rock derived from an original shale-type sedimentary rock composed of clay or volcanic ash through low-grade, regional metamorphism. It is the finest-grained foliated metamorphic rock. Foliation may not correspond to the original sedimentary layering, but instead is in planes perpendicular to the direction of metamorphic compression.The foliation in slate, called "slaty cleavage", is caused by strong compression in which fine-grained clay forms flakes to regrow in planes perpendicular to the compression. When expertly "cut" by striking parallel to the foliation, with a specialized tool in the quarry, many slates display a property called fissility, forming smooth, flat sheets of stone, which have long been used for roofing, floor tiles, and other purposes. Slate is frequently grey in color, especially when seen en masse covering roofs.
wikiDescription: Metamorphic rock

name: Diorite
description: A grey to dark-grey intermediate intrusive igneous rock composed principally of plagioclase feldspar, biotite, hornblende, and pyroxene.
wikiExtract:
Diorite ( DY-ə-ryte) is an intrusive igneous rock formed by the slow cooling underground of magma (molten rock) that has a moderate content of silica and a relatively low content of alkali metals. It is intermediate in composition between low-silica (mafic) gabbro and high-silica (felsic) granite.
Diorite is found in mountain-building belts (orogens) on the margins of continents. It has the same composition as the fine-grained volcanic rock, andesite, which is also common in orogens.
Diorite has been used since prehistoric times as decorative stone.
wikiDescription: Igneous rock type

name: Gabbro
description: A dark, coarse-grained, intrusive mafic igneous rocks chemically equivalent to basalt, being its coarse-grained analogue.
wikiExtract: Gabbro () is a phaneritic (coarse-grained), mafic intrusive igneous rock formed from the slow cooling of magnesium-rich and iron-rich magma into a holocrystalline mass deep beneath the Earth's surface. Slow-cooling, coarse-grained gabbro is chemically equivalent to rapid-cooling, fine-grained basalt. Much of the Earth's oceanic crust is made of gabbro, formed at mid-ocean ridges. Gabbro is also found as plutons associated with continental volcanism. Due to its variant nature, the term gabbro may be applied loosely to a wide range of intrusive rocks, many of which are merely "gabbroic".
wikiDescription: Coarse-grained mafic intrusive rock

name: Obsidian
description: A naturally occurring volcanic glass formed as an extrusive igneous rock. It is produced when felsic lava extruded from a volcano cools rapidly with minimal crystal growth.
wikiExtract: Obsidian () is a naturally occurring volcanic glass formed when lava extruded from a volcano cools rapidly with minimal crystal growth. It is an igneous rock.Obsidian is produced from felsic lava, rich in the lighter elements such as silicon, oxygen, aluminium, sodium, and potassium. It is commonly found within the margins of rhyolitic lava flows known as obsidian flows. These flows have a high content of silica, granting them a high viscosity. The high viscosity inhibits diffusion of atoms through the lava, which inhibits the first step (nucleation) in the formation of mineral crystals.
wikiDescription: Naturally occurring volcanic glass

name: Pumice
description: A type of extrusive volcanic rock, produced when lava with a very high content of water and gases is discharged from a volcano.
wikiExtract: Pumice ( ), called pumicite in its powdered or dust form, is a volcanic rock that consists of highly vesicular rough-textured volcanic glass, which may or may not contain crystals. It is typically light-colored. Scoria is another vesicular volcanic rock that differs from pumice in having larger vesicles, thicker vesicle walls, and being dark colored and denser.Pumice is created when super-heated, highly pressurized rock is rapidly ejected from a volcano. The unusual foamy configuration of pumice happens because of simultaneous rapid cooling and rapid depressurization. The depressurization creates bubbles by lowering the solubility of gases (including water and CO2) that are dissolved in the lava, causing the gases to rapidly exsolve (like the bubbles of CO2 that appear when a carbonated drink is opened).
wikiDescription: Light colored highly vesicular volcanic rock

name: Rhyolite
description: A light-colored, fine-grained, extrusive igneous rock that typically contains quartz and feldspar minerals.
wikiExtract:
Rhyolite ( RY-ə-lyte) is the most silica-rich of volcanic rocks. It is generally glassy or fine-grained (aphanitic) in texture, but may be porphyritic, containing larger mineral crystals (phenocrysts) in an otherwise fine-grained groundmass. The mineral assemblage is predominantly quartz, sanidine, and plagioclase. It is the extrusive equivalent to granite.
Rhyolitic magma is extremely viscous, due to its high silica content.
wikiDescription: Igneous, volcanic rock, of felsic (silica-rich) composition

name: Andesite
description: An extrusive rock, intermediate in composition between rhyolite and basalt, typically porphyritic, containing larger crystals (phenocrysts) set in a fine-grained groundmass.
wikiExtract: Andesite () is a volcanic rock of intermediate composition. In a general sense, it is the intermediate type between silica-poor basalt and silica-rich rhyolite. It is fine-grained (aphanitic) to porphyritic in texture, and is composed predominantly of sodium-rich plagioclase plus pyroxene or hornblende.Andesite is the extrusive equivalent of plutonic diorite. Characteristic of subduction zones, andesite represents the dominant rock type in island arcs. The average composition of the continental crust is andesitic.
wikiDescription: Type of volcanic rock

name: Pegmatite
description: A very coarse-grained igneous rock, with grain size over 2 cm, which often contains rare minerals not found in other rocks.
wikiExtract:
A pegmatite is an igneous rock showing a very coarse texture, with large interlocking crystals usually greater in size than 1 cm (0.4 in) and sometimes greater than 1 meter (3 ft). Most pegmatites are composed of quartz, feldspar, and mica, having a similar silicic composition to granite. However, rarer intermediate composition and mafic pegmatites are known.
Many of the world's largest crystals are found within pegmatites. These include crystals of microcline, quartz, mica, spodumene, beryl, and tourmaline.
wikiDescription: Igneous rock with very large interlocked crystals

name: Peridotite
description: A dense, coarse-grained igneous rock, consisting mostly of the minerals olivine and pyroxene. Peridotite is ultramafic, as the rock contains less than 45% silica.
wikiExtract: Peridotite (US:  PERR-ih-doh-tyte, pə-RID-ə-) is a dense, coarse-grained igneous rock consisting mostly of the silicate minerals olivine and pyroxene. Peridotite is ultramafic, as the rock contains less than 45% silica. It is high in magnesium (Mg2+), reflecting the high proportions of magnesium-rich olivine, with appreciable iron. Peridotite is derived from Earth's mantle, either as solid blocks and fragments, or as crystals accumulated from magmas that formed in the mantle. The compositions of peridotites from these layered igneous complexes vary widely, reflecting the relative proportions of pyroxenes, chromite, plagioclase, and amphibole.
wikiDescription: Coarse-grained ultramafic igneous rock type

name: Scoria
description: A dark-colored, vesicular, extrusive igneous rock. The vesicles are a result of trapped gas within the melt at the time of solidification.
wikiExtract:
Scoria is a pyroclastic, highly vesicular, dark-colored volcanic rock that was ejected from a volcano as a molten blob and cooled in the air to form discrete grains or clasts. It is typically dark in color (generally dark brown, black or purplish-red), and basaltic or andesitic in composition. Scoria is relatively low in density as a result of its numerous macroscopic ellipsoidal vesicles, but in contrast to pumice, all scoria has a specific gravity greater than 1 and sinks in water. 
The holes or vesicles form when gases that were dissolved in the magma come out of solution as it erupts, creating bubbles in the molten rock, some of which are frozen in place as the rock cools and solidifies. Scoria may form as part of a lava flow, typically near its surface, or as fragmental ejecta (lapilli, blocks and bombs), for instance in Strombolian eruptions that form steep-sided scoria cones.
wikiDescription: Dark vesicular volcanic rock

name: Tuff
description: A type of rock made of volcanic ash ejected from a vent during a volcanic eruption. Following ejection and deposition, the ash is compacted into a solid rock in a process called consolidation.
wikiExtract: Tuff is a type of rock made of volcanic ash ejected from a vent during a volcanic eruption. Following ejection and deposition, the ash is lithified into a solid rock. Rock that contains greater than 75% ash is considered tuff, while rock containing 25% to 75% ash is described as tuffaceous (for example, tuffaceous sandstone). Tuff composed of sandy volcanic material can be referred to as volcanic sandstone.Tuff is a relatively soft rock, so it has been used for construction since ancient times. Because it is common in Italy, the Romans used it often for construction.
wikiDescription: Rock consolidated from volcanic ash

name: Shale
description: A fine-grained sedimentary rock that forms from the compaction of silt and clay-size mineral particles, often contains fossils.
wikiExtract: Shale is a fine-grained, clastic sedimentary rock formed from mud that is a mix of flakes of clay minerals (hydrous aluminium phyllosilicates, e.g. kaolin, Al2Si2O5(OH)4) and tiny fragments (silt-sized particles) of other minerals, especially quartz and calcite.  Shale is characterized by its tendency to split into thin layers (laminae) less than one centimeter in thickness. This property is called fissility. Shale is the most common sedimentary rock.The term shale is sometimes applied more broadly, as essentially a synonym for mudrock, rather than in the more narrow sense of clay-rich fissile mudrock.
wikiDescription: Fine-grained, clastic sedimentary rock

name: Conglomerate
description: A coarse-grained sedimentary rock composed of rounded fragments within a matrix of finer grained material.
wikiExtract: Conglomerate or conglomeration may refer to:
wikiDescription: Topics referred to by the same term

name: Breccia
description: A rock composed of broken fragments of minerals or rock cemented together by a fine-grained matrix.
wikiExtract:
Breccia () is a rock composed of large angular broken fragments of minerals or rocks cemented together by a fine-grained matrix.
The word has its origins in the Italian language, in which it means "rubble". A breccia may have a variety of different origins, as indicated by the named types including sedimentary breccia, tectonic breccia, igneous breccia, impact breccia, and hydrothermal breccia.
A megabreccia is a breccia composed of very large rock fragments, sometimes kilometers across, which can be formed by landslides, impact events, or caldera collapse.
wikiDescription: Rock composed of broken fragments cemented by a matrix

name: Chalk
description: A soft, white, porous sedimentary rock which is a form of limestone composed of the mineral calcite.
wikiExtract:
Chalk is a soft, white, porous, sedimentary carbonate rock. It is a form of limestone composed of the mineral calcite and originally formed deep under the sea by the compression of microscopic plankton that had settled to the sea floor. Chalk is common throughout Western Europe, where deposits underlie parts of France, and steep cliffs are often seen where they meet the sea in places such as the Dover cliffs on the Kent coast of the English Channel.
Chalk is mined for use in industry, such as for quicklime, bricks and builder's putty, and in agriculture, for raising pH in soils with high acidity. It is also used for "blackboard chalk" for writing and drawing on various types of surfaces, although these can also be manufactured from other carbonate-based minerals, or gypsum.
wikiDescription: Soft, white, porous sedimentary rock made of calcium carbonate

name: Coal
description: A black or brownish-black sedimentary rock that's primarily composed of carbon along with various other elements, such as hydrogen, sulfur, oxygen, and nitrogen.
wikiExtract:
Coal is a combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock, formed as rock strata called coal seams. Coal is mostly carbon with variable amounts of other elements, chiefly hydrogen, sulfur, oxygen, and nitrogen.
Coal is a type of fossil fuel, formed when dead plant matter decays into peat and is converted into coal by the heat and pressure of deep burial over millions of years. Vast deposits of coal originate in former wetlands called coal forests that covered much of the Earth's tropical land areas during the late Carboniferous (Pennsylvanian) and Permian times. Many significant coal deposits are younger than this and originate from the Mesozoic and Cenozoic eras.
wikiDescription: Combustible sedimentary rock composed primarily of carbon

name: Dolomite
description: A sedimentary rock similar to limestone but contains magnesium as well as calcium.
wikiExtract: Dolomite may refer to:
wikiDescription: Topics referred to by the same term

name: Flint
description: A hard sedimentary rock, a variety of quartz, used in the past for making tools and recently for building walls.
wikiExtract:
Flint, occasionally flintstone, is a sedimentary cryptocrystalline form of the mineral quartz, categorized as the variety of chert that occurs in chalk or marly limestone. Flint was widely used historically to make stone tools and start fires.
Flint occurs chiefly as nodules and masses in sedimentary rocks, such as chalks and limestones. Inside the nodule, flint is usually dark grey or black, green, white, or brown in colour, and has a glassy or waxy appearance. A thin, oxidised layer on the outside of the nodules is usually different in colour, typically white and rough in texture.
wikiDescription: Cryptocrystalline form of the mineral quartz

name: Gypsum
description: A sedimentary rock composed primarily of calcium sulfate dihydrate, widely used for plaster, wallboard and sculptures.
wikiExtract:
Gypsum is a soft sulfate mineral composed of calcium sulfate dihydrate, with the chemical formula CaSO4·2H2O. It is widely mined and is used as a fertilizer and as the main constituent in many forms of plaster, blackboard or sidewalk chalk, and drywall. Alabaster, a fine-grained white or lightly tinted variety of gypsum, has been used for sculpture by many cultures including Ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, Ancient Rome, the Byzantine Empire, and the Nottingham alabasters of Medieval England. Gypsum also crystallizes as translucent crystals of selenite. It forms as an evaporite mineral and as a hydration product of anhydrite.
The Mohs scale of mineral hardness defines gypsum as hardness value 2 based on scratch hardness comparison.
wikiDescription: Soft calcium sulfate mineral

name: Lignite
description: A soft, brownish coal showing traces of plant structure, intermediate between bituminous coal and peat.
wikiExtract:
Lignite, often referred to as brown coal, is a soft, brown, combustible, sedimentary rock formed from naturally compressed peat. It has a carbon content around 25–35%, and is considered the lowest rank of coal due to its relatively low heat content. When removed from the ground, it contains a very high amount of moisture which partially explains its low carbon content. Lignite is mined all around the world and is used almost exclusively as a fuel for steam-electric power generation.
The combustion for lignite produces less heat for the amount of carbon dioxide and sulfur released than other ranks of coal.
wikiDescription: Soft, brown, combustible, sedimentary rock

name: Chert
description: A hard, dense, sedimentary rock composed of microcrystalline quartz.
wikiExtract: Chert () is a hard, fine-grained sedimentary rock composed of microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline quartz, the mineral form of silicon dioxide (SiO2). Chert is characteristically of biological origin, but may also occur inorganically as a chemical precipitate or a diagenetic replacement, as in petrified wood.Chert is typically composed of the petrified remains of siliceous ooze, the biogenic sediment that covers large areas of the deep ocean floor, and which contains the silicon skeletal remains of diatoms, silicoflagellates, and radiolarians. Precambrian cherts are notable for the presence of fossil cyanobacteria. In addition to microfossils, chert occasionally contains macrofossils. However, some chert is devoid of any fossils.Chert varies greatly in color, from white to black, but is most often found as gray, brown, grayish brown and light green to rusty red and occasionally as dark green.
wikiDescription: Hard, fine-grained sedimentary rock composed of cryptocrystalline silica

name: Oolite
description: A sedimentary rock formed from ooids, spherical grains composed of concentric layers.
wikiExtract: Oolite or oölite (from Ancient Greek  ᾠόν (ōión) 'egg stone') is a sedimentary rock formed from ooids, spherical grains composed of concentric layers. Strictly, oolites consist of ooids of diameter 0.25–2 millimetres; rocks composed of ooids larger than 2 mm are called pisolites. The term oolith can refer to oolite or individual ooids.
wikiDescription: Sedimentary rock formed from ooids

name: Travertine
description: A form of limestone deposited by mineral springs, especially hot springs.
wikiExtract: Travertine ( TRAV-ər-teen) is a form of terrestrial limestone deposited around mineral springs, especially hot springs. It often has a fibrous or concentric appearance and exists in white, tan, cream-colored, and even rusty varieties. It is formed by a process of rapid precipitation of calcium carbonate, often at the mouth of a hot spring or in a limestone cave. In the latter, it can form stalactites, stalagmites, and other speleothems. It is frequently used in Italy and elsewhere as a building material.
wikiDescription: Form of limestone deposited by mineral springs

name: Siltstone
description: A fine-grained sedimentary rock which is formed by the consolidation and compaction of silt.
wikiExtract: Siltstone, also known as aleurolite, is a clastic sedimentary rock that is composed mostly of silt. It is a form of mudrock with a low clay mineral content, which can be distinguished from shale by its lack of fissility.Although its permeability and porosity is relatively low, siltstone is sometimes a tight gas reservoir rock, an unconventional reservoir for natural gas that requires hydraulic fracturing for economic gas production.Siltstone was prized in ancient Egypt for manufacturing statuary and cosmetic palettes. The siltstone quarried at Wadi Hammamat was a hard, fine-grained siltstone that resisted flaking and was almost ideal for such uses.
wikiDescription: Sedimentary rock which has a grain size in the silt range

name: Peat
description: A brown, soil-like material characterized by its high carbon content, formed from the remains of decayed plants over thousands of years.
wikiExtract: Peat () is an accumulation of partially decayed vegetation or organic matter. It is unique to natural areas called peatlands, bogs, mires, moors, or muskegs. The peatland ecosystem covers 3.7 million square kilometres (1.4 million square miles) and is the most efficient carbon sink on the planet, because peatland plants capture carbon dioxide (CO2) naturally released from the peat, maintaining an equilibrium. In natural peatlands, the "annual rate of biomass production is greater than the rate of decomposition", but it takes "thousands of years for peatlands to develop the deposits of 1.5 to 2.3 m [4.9 to 7.5 ft], which is the average depth of the boreal [northern] peatlands", which store around 415 gigatonnes (Gt) of carbon (about 46 times 2019 global CO2 emissions). Globally, peat stores up to 550 Gt of carbon, 42% of all soil carbon, which exceeds the carbon stored in all other vegetation types, including the world's forests, although it covers just 3% of the land's surface.Sphagnum moss, also called peat moss, is one of the most common components in peat, although many other plants can contribute.
wikiDescription: Accumulation of partially decayed vegetation

name: Loess
description: A wind-blown sediment of silt-sized particles, typically light brown, loosely cemented by calcium carbonate.
wikiExtract: A loess (US: , UK: ; from German: Löss [lœs]) is a clastic, predominantly silt-sized sediment that is formed by the accumulation of wind-blown dust. Ten percent of Earth's land area is covered by loesses or similar deposits.A loess is a periglacial or aeolian (windborne) sediment, defined as an accumulation of 20% or less of clay with a balance of roughly equal parts sand and silt (with a typical grain size from 20 to 50 micrometers), often loosely cemented by calcium carbonate. Usually, they are homogeneous and highly porous and have vertical capillaries that permit the sediment to fracture and form vertical bluffs.
wikiDescription: Sediment of accumulated wind-blown dust

name: Mudstone
description: A type of mudrock whose original constituents were clays or muds. Grain size is up to 0.0625 mm with individual grains too small to be distinguished without a microscope.
wikiExtract: Mudstone, a type of mudrock, is a fine-grained sedimentary rock whose original constituents were clays or muds. Mudstone is distinguished from shale by its lack of fissility (parallel layering).The term mudstone is also used to describe carbonate rocks (limestone or dolomite) that are composed predominantly of carbonate mud. However, in most contexts, the term refers to siliciclastic mudstone, composed mostly of silicate minerals.The NASA Curiosity rover has found deposits of mudstone on Mars that contain organic substances such as propane, benzene and toluene.
wikiDescription: Fine grained sedimentary rock whose original constituents were clays or muds

name: Oil Shale
description: A fine-grained sedimentary rock that contains significant amounts of kerogen (a solid mixture of organic chemical compounds), from which liquid hydrocarbons can be produced.
wikiExtract: Oil shale is an organic-rich fine-grained sedimentary rock containing kerogen (a solid mixture of organic chemical compounds) from which liquid hydrocarbons can be produced. In addition to kerogen, general composition of oil shales constitutes inorganic substance and bitumens. Based on their deposition environment, oil shales are classified as marine, lacustrine and terrestrial oil shales. Oil shales differ from oil-bearing shales, shale deposits that contain petroleum (tight oil) that is sometimes produced from drilled wells. Examples of oil-bearing shales are the Bakken Formation, Pierre Shale, Niobrara Formation, and Eagle Ford Formation.
wikiDescription: Organic-rich fine-grained sedimentary rock containing kerogen

name: Arkose
description: A type of sandstone containing at least 25% feldspar.
wikiExtract:
Arkose () or arkosic sandstone is a detrital sedimentary rock, specifically a type of sandstone containing at least 25% feldspar. Arkosic sand is sand that is similarly rich in feldspar, and thus the potential precursor of arkose. 
Quartz is commonly the dominant mineral component, and some mica is often present. Apart from the mineral content, rock fragments may also be a significant component. Arkose usually contains small amounts of calcite cement, which causes it to effervesce (fizz) slightly in dilute hydrochloric acid; sometimes the cement also contains iron oxide.
wikiDescription: Type of sandstone containing at least 25% feldspar

name: Greywacke
description: A variety of sandstone generally characterized by its hardness, dark color, and poorly sorted angular grains of quartz, feldspar, and small rock fragments set in a compact, clay-fine matrix.
wikiExtract:
Greywacke or graywacke (German grauwacke, signifying a grey, earthy rock) is a variety of sandstone generally characterized by its hardness, dark color, and poorly sorted angular grains of quartz, feldspar, and small rock fragments or lithic fragments set in a compact, clay-fine matrix. It is a texturally immature sedimentary rock generally found in Paleozoic strata. The larger grains can be sand- to gravel-sized, and matrix materials generally constitute more than 15% of the rock by volume. The term "greywacke" can be confusing, since it can refer to either the immature (rock fragment) aspect of the rock or its fine-grained (clay) component.
The origin of greywacke was unknown until turbidity currents and turbidites were understood, since, according to the normal laws of sedimentation, gravel, sand and mud should not be laid down together.
wikiDescription: Hard, dark sandstone with poorly sorted angular grains in a compact, clay-fine matrix

name: Phosphorite
description: A type of rock primarily rich in phosphate. Its deposition can be marine or terrestrial.
wikiExtract: Phosphorite, phosphate rock or rock phosphate is a non-detrital sedimentary rock that contains high amounts of phosphate minerals. The phosphate content of phosphorite (or grade of phosphate rock) varies greatly, from 4% to 20% phosphorus pentoxide (P2O5). Marketed phosphate rock is enriched ("beneficiated") to at least 28%, often more than 30% P2O5. This occurs through washing, screening, de-liming, magnetic separation or flotation. By comparison, the average phosphorus content of sedimentary rocks is less than 0.2%.
wikiDescription: Sedimentary rock containing large amounts of phosphate minerals

name: Marble
description: A metamorphic rock composed of recrystallized carbonate minerals, most commonly calcite or dolomite.
wikiExtract:
Marble is a metamorphic rock consisting of carbonate minerals that recrystallize under the influence of heat, pressure and aqueous solutions, most commonly calcite  (CaCO3) or dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2) and has a crystalline texture of varying thickness. Marble is typically not foliated (layered), although there are exceptions.
In geology, the term marble refers to metamorphosed limestone, but its use in stonemasonry more broadly encompasses unmetamorphosed limestone. Marble is commonly used for sculpture and as a building material.
wikiDescription: Type of rock

name: Quartzite
description: A hard metamorphic rock which was originally sandstone. Through heating and pressure usually related to tectonic compression, its sand grains are welded together.
wikiExtract:
Quartzite is a hard, non-foliated metamorphic rock which was originally pure quartz sandstone. Sandstone is converted into quartzite through heating and pressure usually related to tectonic compression within orogenic belts. Pure quartzite is usually white to grey, though quartzites often occur in various shades of pink and red due to varying amounts of hematite. Other colors, such as yellow, green, blue  and orange, are due to other minerals.
The term quartzite is also sometimes used for very hard but unmetamorphosed sandstones that are composed of quartz grains thoroughly cemented with additional quartz.
wikiDescription: Hard, non-foliated metamorphic rock which was originally pure quartz sandstone

name: Schist
description: A medium-grade metamorphic rock with medium to large, flat, sheet-like grains in a preferred orientation.
wikiExtract:
Schist ( SHIST) is a medium-grained metamorphic rock showing pronounced schistosity. This means that the rock is composed of mineral grains easily seen with a low-power hand lens, oriented in such a way that the rock is easily split into thin flakes or plates. This texture reflects a high content of platy minerals, such as micas, talc, chlorite, or graphite. These are often interleaved with more granular minerals, such as feldspar or quartz.
Schist typically forms during regional metamorphism accompanying the process of mountain building (orogeny) and usually reflects a medium grade of metamorphism.
wikiDescription: Easily split medium-grained metamorphic rock

name: Gneiss
description: A high-grade metamorphic rock in which mineral grains recrystallized under intense heat and pressure.
wikiExtract:
Gneiss ( NICE) is a common and widely distributed type of metamorphic rock. It is formed by high-temperature and high-pressure metamorphic processes acting on formations composed of igneous or sedimentary rocks. Gneiss forms at higher temperatures and pressures than schist. Gneiss nearly always shows a banded texture characterized by alternating darker and lighter colored bands and without a distinct cleavage.
Gneisses are common in the ancient crust of continental shields.
wikiDescription: Common high-grade metamorphic rock

name: Amphibolite
description: A metamorphic rock that consists mainly of amphibole and plagioclase.
wikiExtract:
Amphibolite () is a metamorphic rock that contains amphibole, especially hornblende and actinolite, as well as plagioclase feldspar, but with little or no quartz. It is typically dark-colored and dense, with a weakly foliated or schistose (flaky) structure. The small flakes of black and white in the rock often give it a salt-and-pepper appearance.
Amphibolite frequently forms by metamorphism of mafic igneous rocks, such as basalt. However, because metamorphism creates minerals entirely based upon the chemistry of the protolith, certain 'dirty marls' and volcanic sediments may also metamorphose to an amphibolite assemblage.
wikiDescription: A metamorphic rock containing mainly amphibole and plagioclase

name: Phyllite
description: A type of foliated metamorphic rock created from slate that is further metamorphosed so that very fine grained white mica achieves a preferred orientation.
wikiExtract: Phyllite ( FIL-yte) is a type of foliated metamorphic rock formed from slate that is further metamorphosed so that very fine grained white mica achieves a preferred orientation. It is primarily composed of quartz, sericite mica, and chlorite.Phyllite has fine-grained mica flakes, whereas slate has extremely fine mica flakes, and schist has large mica flakes, all mica flakes of which have achieved a preferred orientation. Among foliated metamorphic rocks, it represents a gradation in the degree of metamorphism between slate and schist.The minute crystals of graphite, sericite, or chlorite, or the translucent fine-grained white mica, impart a silky, sometimes golden sheen to the surfaces of cleavage, called "phyllitic luster".The word comes from the Greek phyllon, meaning "leaf".The protolith (or parent rock) for phyllite is shale or pelite; or slate, which in turn came from a shale protolith. Its constituent platy minerals are larger than those in slate but are not visible with the naked eye. Phyllites are said to have a texture called "phyllitic sheen," and are usually classified as having formed through low-grade metamorphic conditions through regional metamorphism metamorphic facies.
wikiDescription: Type of foliated metamorphic rock

name: Migmatite
description: A rock at the frontier between igneous and metamorphic rocks. They can also be known as diatexite.
wikiExtract: Migmatite is a composite rock found in medium and high-grade metamorphic environments, commonly within Precambrian cratonic blocks. It consists of two or more constituents often layered repetitively: one layer is an older metamorphic rock that was reconstituted subsequently by partial melting ("neosome"), while the alternate layer has a pegmatitic, aplitic, granitic or generally plutonic appearance ("paleosome"). Commonly, migmatites occur below deformed metamorphic rocks that represent the base of eroded mountain chains.Migmatites form under extreme temperature and pressure conditions during prograde metamorphism, when partial melting occurs in metamorphic paleosome. Components exsolved by partial melting are called neosome (meaning ‘new body’), which may or may not be heterogeneous at the microscopic to macroscopic scale. Migmatites often appear as tightly, incoherently folded veins (ptygmatic folds).
wikiDescription: Mixture of metamorphic rock and igneous rock

name: Eclogite
description: A high-pressure, high-temperature metamorphic rock that forms from basaltic and gabbroic precursors.
wikiExtract: Eclogite ( ) is a metamorphic rock containing garnet (almandine-pyrope) hosted in a matrix of sodium-rich pyroxene (omphacite). Accessory minerals include kyanite, rutile, quartz, lawsonite, coesite, amphibole, phengite, paragonite, zoisite, dolomite, corundum and, rarely, diamond. The chemistry of primary and accessory minerals is used to classify three types of eclogite (A, B, and C). The broad range of eclogitic compositions has led a longstanding debate on the origin of eclogite xenoliths as subducted, altered oceanic crust.
wikiDescription: A dense metamorphic rock formed under high pressure

name: Soapstone
description: A type of metamorphic rock that is largely composed of the mineral talc, and is thus rich in magnesium.
wikiExtract: Soapstone (also known as steatite or soaprock) is a talc-schist, which is a type of metamorphic rock.  It is composed largely of the magnesium rich mineral talc.  It is produced by dynamothermal metamorphism and metasomatism, which occur in the zones where tectonic plates are subducted, changing rocks by heat and pressure, with influx of fluids, but without melting. It has been a medium for carving for thousands of years.
wikiDescription: Talc-bearing metamorphic rock

name: Blueschist
description: A metavolcanic rock that forms by the metamorphism of basalt and rocks with similar composition at high pressures and low temperatures.
wikiExtract:
Blueschist ( ), also called glaucophane schist, is a metavolcanic rock that forms by the metamorphism of basalt and rocks with similar composition at high pressures and low temperatures (200–500 °C (392–932 °F)), approximately corresponding to a depth of 15–30 km (9.3–18.6 mi). The blue color of the rock comes from the presence of the predominant minerals glaucophane and lawsonite.
Blueschists are schists typically found within orogenic belts as terranes of lithology in faulted contact with greenschist or rarely eclogite facies rocks.
wikiDescription: Type of metavolcanic rock

name: Greenstone
description: An altered basalt or chert. It is often used by gold miners for it often contains gold.
wikiExtract: Greenstone may refer to:
wikiDescription: Topics referred to by the same term

name: Serpentinite
description: A rock composed of one or more serpentine group minerals. Minerals in this group are formed by serpentinization, a hydration and metamorphic transformation of ultramafic rock from the Earth's mantle.
wikiExtract: Serpentinite is a rock composed predominantly of one or more serpentine group minerals, the name originating from the similarity of the texture of the rock to that of the skin of a snake. Serpentinite has been called serpentine or serpentine rock, particularly in older geological texts and in wider cultural settings.
wikiDescription: Rock formed by hydration and metamorphic transformation of olivine

name: Hornfels
description: A fine-grained metamorphic rock formed by the action of heat on clay rocks, known as contact metamorphism.
wikiExtract: Hornfels is the group name for a set of contact metamorphic rocks that have been baked and hardened by the heat of intrusive igneous masses and have been rendered massive, hard, splintery, and in some cases exceedingly tough and durable. These properties are due to fine grained non-aligned crystals with platy or prismatic habits, characteristic of metamorphism at high temperature but without accompanying deformation.  The term is derived from the German word Hornfels, meaning "hornstone", because of its exceptional toughness and texture both reminiscent of animal horns. These rocks were referred to by miners in northern England as whetstones.Most hornfels are fine-grained, and while the original rocks (such as sandstone, shale, slate and limestone) may have been more or less fissile owing to the presence of bedding or cleavage planes, this structure is effaced or rendered inoperative in the hornfels.
